documentType: last will and testament with codicils
summary: This document is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated December 11, 2001, along with five subsequent codicils (amendments) dated 2003, 2004, and 2007. It details the disposition of his estate to a trust, appoints and changes executors, and grants them broad powers. The codicils show a progression of changes to the executor appointments and their compensation.

events.title: Execution of Original Will
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signs his original last will and testament in the U.S. Virgin Islands, leaving all property to The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust One and appointing initial executors.

events.title: First Codicil to Will
events.description: Epstein executes the first amendment to his will, replacing the original executors (Schantz and Hoffman) with Henry Jarecki and James Cayne, and naming Paul Hoffman as successor.

events.title: Second Codicil to Will
events.description: Epstein executes the second amendment, adding Lawrence Newman as a third executor alongside Jarecki and Cayne, and again naming Paul Hoffman as successor.

events.title: Third Codicil to Will
events.description: Epstein executes the third amendment, changing the designated successor executor from Paul Hoffman to Darren K. Indyke and increasing executor compensation to $250,000.

events.title: Fifth Codicil to Will
events.description: Epstein executes the fifth amendment, increasing the compensation for each executor to $500,000.

keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein's entire estate was bequeathed to 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2001 Trust One,' a trust he created on November 8, 2001.
The executors of the estate were changed multiple times between 2001 and 2007, ultimately settling on Henry Jarecki, James Cayne, and Lawrence Newman, with Darren K. Indyke as successor.
Executor compensation was increased significantly over time, from $100,000 in the original will to $500,000 in the 2007 codicil.
The will grants executors extremely broad and discretionary powers over the estate's assets, including the authority to invest without restriction, operate businesses, and avoid court supervision.
The document includes a 'no-contest' clause, disinheriting any beneficiary who challenges the will or the trust.
